definition: fragrance/warm/to educate/variant of 熏[xun1]/to smoke/to fumigate

sentences.english: Growing up in a family of musicians, he was saturated with music at an early age.
sentences.chinese: 他在音樂世家長大，小時候就飽受音樂薰陶。

sentences.english: Nobody supervised our reading. We were on our own.
sentences.chinese: 讀書看報，無人監督，純屬自願，自我薰陶。

sentences.english: His success can't be separated from the nurture and edification of Yimeng Culture.
sentences.chinese: 諸葛亮的成才離不開沂蒙文化對他的哺育與薰陶。

sentences.english: Mr. C needs not merely to pursue knowledge, but to cultivate his personality.
sentences.chinese: 先生不但要追求知識，也要薰陶品格。

sentences.english: We want to expose the kids to as much art and culture as possible.
sentences.chinese: 我們想要小孩儘可能多經歷一些藝術與文化的薰陶。

sentences.english: It is the responsibility of parents to cultivate their children to be law-abiding members of society.
sentences.chinese: 父母有責任把他們兒女薰陶成社會守法的一員。

sentences.english: In this kind of temperament, I passed the edification of one another.
sentences.chinese: 在這種氣質的薰陶中，我走過一個又一個春秋。

sentences.english: To learn ancient prose is to accept the influence and teaching of traditional culture.
sentences.chinese: 學習古詩文就是在接受傳統文化的薰陶與教化。

sentences.english: Because his home schooled, Li Shizhen enjoyed medicine from childhood.
sentences.chinese: 由於家庭的薰陶，李時珍從小就喜愛醫藥。

definition: Yan Fu (1853-1921), influential Chinese writer and translator of Western books, esp. on social sciences
the cassock and alms bowl of a Buddhist master passed on to the favorite disciple (Buddhism)/legacy/mantle
cultured and refined (idiom); gentle and cultivated
Xu Dishan (1893-1941), journalist, publisher and novelist
equally proficient in intellectual and military affairs
